description: From Middle English ese, eise, aise, from Anglo-Norman ese (‚Äúease‚Äù), from Old French eise, aise (‚Äúelbow room; opportunity‚Äù), of uncertain and obscure origin. Apparently related to Proven√ßal ais, Italian agio and asio,  Sicilian aciu and  Portuguese azo. Sometimes ascribed to Vulgar Latin *ƒÅsia or *ƒÅsium, possibly from Latin ƒÅnsa (‚Äúhandle, haft‚Äù) or Frankish *ansiju (‚Äúhandle, loophole, eyelet; cup-handle; arms akimbo, elbow room‚Äù), but more often derived from Vulgar Latin *adjace(m), from Latin adjacƒìns (‚Äúadjacent, neighbouring‚Äù), present participle of adjace≈ç (‚Äúlie next to, border on‚Äù), though the forms and senses are difficult to trace clearly.

Alternatively, possibly from a non-Latin source such as Germanic or Celtic on the basis of the conflicting forms which appear in various Romance languages. Compare Old English ƒ´e√æe (‚Äúeasy‚Äù), Gothic êå∞êå∂êå¥êçÑêåπ (azƒìti, ‚Äúease; pleasure‚Äù), *êå∞êå∂êå¥êçÑêçÉ (*azƒìts, ‚Äúeasy‚Äù), Breton eaz, ez (‚Äúeasy‚Äù), Irish adhais (‚Äúeasy; leisure‚Äù). See also eath.
The verb is from Middle English esen, ultimately of the same origin.

definitionGroups.group: Ability, the means to do something, particularly:

examples: He played the ukelele with ease.

definitionGroups.group: Comfort, a state or quality lacking unpleasantness, particularly:

entries.meaning: Freedom from pain, hardship, and annoyance, sometimes (derogatory, archaic) idleness, sloth.
examples: She enjoyed the ease of living in a house where the servants did all the work.

entries.meaning: Freedom from worry and concern; peace; sometimes (derogatory, archaic) indifference.
examples: The pension set her mind at ease.
He passed all the exams with ease.
We took our ease on the patio.

entries.meaning: Freedom from financial effort or worry; affluence.
examples: His inheritance catapulted him into a life of ease.

entries.meaning: Freedom from embarrassment or awkwardness; grace.
examples: She dealt with the faculty with combined authority and ease.

definitionGroups.group: Relief, an end to discomfort, particularly:

entries.meaning: Followed by of or from: release from or reduction of pain, hardship, or annoyance.
examples: Take one pill every 12 hours to provide ease from pain.

entries.meaning: (euphemistic, obsolete) Release from intestinal discomfort: defecation.
Release from constraint, obligation, or a constrained position.
(clothing) Additional space provided to allow greater movement.
examples: Add some ease to the waist measurement.

verbs.description: ease (third-person singular simple present eases, present participle easing, simple past and past participle eased)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To free (something) from pain, worry, agitation, etc.
examples: He eased his conscience by confessing.
He loosened his shoe to ease the pain.
His words of comfort eased his friend's pain and distress.
The provision of extra staff eased their workload.

entries.meaning: (nautical, transitive) To loosen or slacken the tension on a line.
examples: We eased the boom vang, then lowered the sail.
We had to ease the entry requirements.
He eased the cork from the bottle.
The car eased onto the motorway.
